Diffuse color (aka albedo), defining what ratio of light is reflected – or transmitted – for each color channel.
Shading normal, typically defined by bump or normal mapping. Defaults to the smooth surface normal if not set.
Shading normal, typically defined by bump or normal mapping. Defaults to the smooth surface normal if not set.

Diffuse Mean Free Path, expressed for each color channel in mm. Indicates on average how much the light travels under the surface before being scattered. The higher the value, the softer the result will be. If zero (black), which is the default value, the computation simplifies to a Lambertian reflection lobe with no subsurface scattering.
Multiplies the radius, to adjust its scale to the scene at hand. If zero, the computation simplifies to a Lambertian reflection lobe with no subsurface scattering.

Selects what method should be used to compute sub-surface scattering. The first two options are path-traced variants, with different attenuation strategies applied to the path. The second two are traditional diffusion models. The first Diffusion Burley expects a diffuse mean free path in mm (the average length of a path measured from its entry and exit points after subsurface scattering interactions). The second Diffusion Burley uses mean free path in mm (the average distance that a photon travels in a subsurface volume, which is 1/sigma_t, where sigma_t is the extinction coefficient).

Index of refraction use to trigger cases of total internal reflections, when the paths are reaching the surface after having travelled under it. Can be used to avoid excessive glow in highly curved regions (corners, creases, …).
Higher values makes light scatter predominantly forward under the surface, making the object look less diffuse and more transparent.

Controls the depth of light bleed in the subsurface medium. Has the effect of increasing the distance light travels in the medium while preserving fine detail, compared to increasing the Mean Free Path.

Controls how strongly normals are considered in the subsurface computation. For path-traced sss (sssMode 0 and 1), the followTopology parameter reduces sss paths being blocked by backsides behind a surface, but also reduces sss from one side to another in convex regions such as ridges and ears. For diffusion sss (sssMode 2 and 3), the followTopology parameter reduces sss from one side to another in concave regions such as crevasses and wrinkles.
Specifies trace subset for inclusion/exclusion when struck by a ray indirectly.
When enabled, ignores internal geometry and jumps to the last surface.

This is the multiplier that converts between millimetres and scene units. Both mean free path and diffuse mean free path are specified in millimetres and this parameter is used for the unit conversion. The default value of 0.00328 converts millimetres to feet. For centimetre scene units, this would be 0.1, for metres it would be 0.001 etc.
Decides which albedo inversion methods is used.
When enabled, shadowing from bumped normals is considered. This helps to soften harsh shadow terminators.
Defines the name that can be used in LPE AOVs for the diffuse lobe (when subsurface computation is disabled on LamaSurface).
Defines the name that can be used in LPE AOVs for the SSS Entry lobe.

Defines the name that can be used in LPE AOVs for the SSS Exit lobe. When a pattern network mixes results of several LamaSSS nodes, those nodes must have different sssExitLobeName or different sssId. (Note that the sssExitLobeNames need to be defined as diffuse LPEs.)

Several SSS materials can share the same sssExitLobeName, but if they do, they must have a different sssId. This is necessary when mixing two materials with the same sssExitLobeName. Note that if their lobe names are different, the sssId is irrelevant.
Defines a prefix for the user lobe names that can be used in LPE AOVs  to split them out from user lobes written by other Lama nodes.
Defines the name that can be used by the matte system, to output the weight of this lobe in the final material as an AOV.
